newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - March 12.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - March 12.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN

Australian gold medallist swimmer Susan O'Neill has won the World Trophy for the Oceania region. The Amateur Athletic Federation of Los Angeles recognises an athlete for outstanding performance for each of the six world regions. O'Neill was selected ahead of Olympic 1500 metres champion Kieren Perkins and New Zealand's gold medallist Danyon Loader. Page 20.

Newcastle rugby league player Paul Harragon will be sidelined for at least a month due to continuing migraine headaches. Suffering for headaches for the past month, Harragon was taken from the field on Sunday after receiving two knocks to the head in thematch against St George. Page 20.

Australian cricket captain Mark Taylor's attempts to prove his fitness for the second Test against South Africa suffered a knock back yesterday when he was unable to participate in a low-key one-day Invitational XI. Taylor's back injury is improving although he is still suffering from small spasms. Page 20.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Retired Australian rugby union player David Campese is among the inclusions for the New South Wales side announced yesterday for the Super 12 rugby union clash against Canterbury on Friday night. Selectors overlooked the opportunity to experiment, opting for the return of long-standing campaigners Campese, Sam Domoni and Michael Brial. Page 47.

Italian soccer club Sampdoria is expected to make a A$3 million bid for promising Australian midfielder Josip Skoko. Skoko, 20, is expected to make his Socceroo debut in the World Cup warm-up match against Macedonia tonight. Page 47.

Sydney Kings Matt Nielsen has been selected to play in the world under-20 basketball team to play an American side in Florida next month. Neilsen was the only Australian to be selected in the 12-man team chosen by the World Association of Basketball coaches. Page 47.
THE AGE

The racing career of Doremius is not over despite initial gloomy forecasts after he bled during Monday's Australia Cup at Flemington. Trainer Lee Freedman was yesterday optimistic that the champion horse would return after suitable rest and treatment. Page B16.

Melbourne may not have its own rugby league team until 1999 after delays with both Super League and the Australian Rugby League. Super League chief executive John Ribot said yesterday that a Melbourne-based Super League team could be as far as two years way. Page B14.

The Collingwood Warriors soccer team looks like being axed from the national Ericsson Cup. Soccer Australia has to cut at least one club from the present league to make way for new club Carlton, which starts its first season in October, and the Gippsland Falcons said yesterday their place was virtually assured. Page B14.
THE HERALD SUN

Australian rowing champions, the "Oarsome Foursome" are aiming to collect their third successive gold medal at the Sydney Olympics in 2000. The men have agreed that the lure of a home Olympics has proven too much, and they will compete in the coxless fours. Page 72.

Millward looks set to run in the Golden Slipper Stakes on March 22. This comes after suggestions last week that the champion horse, which won Monday's Simes Produce Stakes at Flemington, would not participate due to the A$100,000 late entry fee Page 69.

The Australian Football League will use a controversial survey as part of its decision-making on the new Docklands Stadium. The survey of 500 football fans showed fans favoured Waverly Park over Optus Oval and showed strong support for the Docklands Stadum. Page 68.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Queensland Reds rugby union winger Barry Lea is to be investigated by South African police after a brawl was sparked when he jumped on top of a pick-up truck early on Sunday morning. Lea had signed with the Canberra Raiders rugby league team the day before. Page 78.

Mark Philippoussis has been rushed into the Australian Davis Cup tennis team following his second title win over the weekend, joining the in-form Pat Rafter, Mark Woodforde and Todd Woodbridge. Team captain John Newcombe said Philippoussis was both in fom and keen to play against the Czech Republic at the Memorial Drive grass courts from April 4-6. Page 73.

Lengthy delays marred the Australian sprint canoe-kayak championships yesterday, when the weed problem which has plagued the Sydney International Regatta Centre returned. Competitors were forced to relocate to the top half of the lake after competitors boats and paddles were virtually choked by weeds. Page 73.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
